Dear Ms. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on April 13, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee Records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
Two of six employee files did not have a written performance evaluation completed on
time.

R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
Rule 152. At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident’s case record:
(a) Name, address, birth date, gender, race, height, weight, hair
color, eye color, identifying marks, religious preference, and school
status.
(d) Name, address, and marital status of parents and name and
address of legal guardian, if known.
(g) Authorization to provide medical, dental, and surgical care and
treatment as provided in section 14 a (1), (2), and (3) of 1973 PA
116, MCL 722.124a.
(h) A brief description of the circumstances leading to the need for
care.
(i) Documentation that the grievance policy was provided as required
in R 400.4132.
Two of three youth files reviewed lacked initial documentation. The two youth moved
from a different license within Eagle Village's campus.
R 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an initial
treatment plan for each resident within 30 calendar days of
admission.
One of three youth files reviewed had an initial treatment plan completed 31 calendar
days from admission.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 1 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. The facility had one maltreatment incident during the period under review.
During a special investigation it was determined a staff member used inappropriate
intervention techniques with a youth, which lead to that staff member having a
confirmed case.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The facility
had nine special investigations with three investigations requiring CAPs during the
period under review. The CAPs addressed one improper restraint, staff not
following the facility's policy and an inappropriate form of intervention by a staff
leading to a confirmed case for that staff member. Ongoing CAP monitoring is
conducted with the facility, and they have complied with all of the CAPs.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on review of the facility's budget
and agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported a supervisor is now at each house, rather than one
supervisor covering both houses. The Chief Administrator stated this has helped
the milieu and the programs be more consistent. The facility has raised the pay rate
and increased recruiting efforts, but staffing continues to be an issue. The Chief
Administrator stated Eagle Village is seeing youth with more difficult behaviors being
placed within the facility.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported having the tools needed to do their job and feeling
supported by management. Staff stated youth are getting what they need and
programming in the houses are going well. One staff reported being able to shadow
multiple staff in different houses helped tremendously when first starting the job.
Youth interviewed reported liking the majority of the staff and that staff do their jobs.
All of the youth interviewed stated they felt safe, have regular groups and
understand the rules of the program.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of both facilities occurred on April 13, 2023.
There were no issues or safety concerns.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
